g.text: Here we quantify recent water cycle change using a new method developed by Zika
. Seawater can only change salinity due to the addition/removal of freshwater, i.e.
), ice melt/freeze etc., or by mixing with waters of differing
salinities. Considering the entire ocean as a volumetric distribution in salinity coordinates (Fig. 1), mixing will
always draw high salinity waters towards low salinity waters collapsing the distribution towards a single value. For
the distribution to be maintained, freshwater must be added to the least saline parts of the distribution and
removed from the most saline parts, drawing the distribution apart. The integral of
) (equal and opposite to the integral over the more saline side of the distribution in
a balanced system) is defined as the oceanic water cycle (
) for the purposes of this study. It is important to
note that this definition considers only the geographical redistribution of water by the atmosphere and hence
It does not necessarily scale with changes in
individually as such changes can compensate
locally and hence no change in salinity. Zika
show that the width of the ocean’s
; defined as the volume weighted mean of
) is related to the water cycle by
is the volume of the ocean.
is the imbalance between the total freshwater added to the fresh side of
the distribution and that added to the saline side (for example due to the melting of glaciers and sea-ice). To first
order if an equal amount of freshwater is added to both sides
does not change. In practice we will assume all
the additional freshwater is from melting glaciers and hence enters the ocean at polar/sub-polar latitudes where
the ocean is fresher than the global mean.
is the diffusive flux of salt across the
ity to the low salinity side of the distribution. The diffusive flux is thought to increase as the contrast between high
increases) and hence is parameterized using an e-folding timescale
We use equation (1) to infer the water cycle change from observed changes in ocean salinity. Historical mean
and trend analysis from three global gridded observational salinity datasets based on
) are used (see Methods). Equation (1) is essentially a salt conser-
vation equation in salinity space where salt mixing is parameterized using a simplified expression. The mixing
parameterization of equation (1) is tested against output from ten state-of-the-art models from the Coupled
Concentration Pathways 4.5 (RCP4.5) and 8.5 (RCP8.5) scenarios (see Methods and Table S1).
Figure 1a shows the historical mean volumetric distribution in salinity coordinates for the En4 observational
dataset and the ten CMIP5 models considered here. Most CMIP5 models show a broader mean volumetric distri-
bution than observations. The CMIP5 ensemble mean
standard deviation, see Methods) as compared to 0.192 for En4. In contrast with the
mean uncertainty in CMIP5 (i.e. average of individual
model standard deviations of the detrended yearly timeseries) is quite small (~0.0012) and comparable to the
Historical mean volumetric distribution and water cycle amplitude in salinity coordinates.
) Historical mean volumetric distribution of sea-water in salinity anomaly (with respect to the global mean
/pss; colours: CMIP5; black: En4 observations); Bars show the mean deviation of salinity
in sea surface salinity anomaly space (Sv/pss; colours: as in (
black: observations CORE2-Dai, dashed black: observations GPCP-OAFLUX-Dai). Bars show accumulated
up to the global mean salinity (
